website_summaries.verdict: Civilization: Beyond Earth takes empire building to the stars with a number of compelling—but familiar—results.
pros: Some new flourishes nicely expand the Civilization concept

I am SOOOOO BUMMED and its the last product I will be buying as I have never once bought a Sid Meiers game and had it work out of the box 9 hours of trouble shooting and updating and trying every online trick I can find its resulted in NOTHING. customer_reviews.author: J. Neef

customer_reviews.title: Slow and beautifully boring
customer_reviews.text: The only good thing about this game is the way it looks. Very disappointing. Most Steam reviewers came from having played Civilization. The same people made Alpha Centauri that I absolutely love still. In BE you are always aware that there is a computer involved. It's slow, glitchy and you hit a lot of "next" waiting for the game to progress. You can't stack "units" and you keep having to get out of your way, which I hate. You have no way of knowing what your other players are doing and you can't see / know what they're doing. This is depressing. I'm going to play Alpha C.
customer_reviews.author: Larry the Good

customer_reviews.title: The Stench of Steam Stinks Up Amazon
customer_reviews.text: I purchased Civilization: Earth. When I tried to download it from Steam, I could not. I reset my password twice. I received two verification codes and "proved" I was human at least eight times. Steam keeps telling me to log into my account. I had to create a "support account". Though I have had to "prove" I was human eight times, I have not been able to contact a human at Steam, I can't download the game and Amazon has a "policy".
customer_reviews.author: Mark LaJoie

customer_reviews.title: ... 5 fan and unfortunately this game is not as good. If you're expecting an experience like Civ 5
customer_reviews.text: I'm a huge Civ 5 fan and unfortunately this game is not as good. If you're expecting an experience like Civ 5, then you'll be disappointed. If you're expecting a great sci-fi game, then you'll be pleased. This game felt flat and monotonous. It's not uncommon for Civ 5 players to spend days-on-end replaying levels. It was a chore to play Beyond Earth for a few hours. The storyline is dull and the upgrade system has a lot to be desired. The game would've been better if "Beyond Earth" and "Starships" were combined into one game with the ability to colonize other planets instead of being "stuck" on one world.
customer_reviews.author: Norman Scott

customer_reviews.title: Disappointed
customer_reviews.text: Highly disappointed with the newest addition to the Civ universe. I was such a huge fan of Civ 5 and have been anticipating the release of Beyond Earth ever since I found out about it. This game truly feels like an advanced mod over Civ 5. It has it's moments, like when you first land onto the alien world (very cool!) so, it's not a complete dud; however, I can't get myself to play more than one time through. This is NOT worth the $60 price tag I paid...if you can get it on sale for $30 or less, go for it and you'll be happy.
customer_reviews.author: DAE Living

customer_reviews.title: The premise is interesting but it got really boring fairly quickly
customer_reviews.text: This game was just so-so and definitely not worth the price I paid for the download. The premise is interesting but it got really boring fairly quickly. I feel like I've been playing for a very long time and still haven't completed the game. I love the earlier civ games and I don't mind playing for long periods of time. This just felt like it went on and on. The graphics aren't all that great. It's hard to really pick one affinity and go with it...just eh.
customer_reviews.author: Joe N.

customer_reviews.title: Civilization: BE...just meh.
customer_reviews.text: It's just like an expansion pack. Glad I got it for $30. Not worth anything above that. They reorganized a lot of the UI. Most of the gameplay is the same just with different names. They did introduce a few new aspects including missions, victories, and Affinities. Affinities are by far the most interesting thing. You can upgrade your troops to one of the three affinity groups. They earn benefits from the group as well. A recent update also fixed a lot of issues with that game. If you're a Civilization fan, this is just more of that same fun, but it's not really anything new.

Someone here said it is a shallow game. I completely disagree. This is quite involved but fun. If you like science, science fiction, conflict (human and otherwise), strategy and tactics, economics, then this is your game.

customer_reviews.title: Civ V Extra Lite
customer_reviews.text: I've played all the CIv games and Alpha Centauri. This is basically a severely dumbed down version of Civ V. Fewer "civilizations" (sponsors) with one trait instead of three. Fewer units. Fewer buildings. Very limited diplomatic options. A cut down version of city states. The tech web is different from the old tech tree, but not better, just more confusing. Its a real shame for the Civ franchise. As is right now, it plays like a skeletal system which they might fill in with some DLC content later on. I paid $25 bucks for it, and I regret it.

customer_reviews.title: This is an excellent addition to this line of games
customer_reviews.text: This is an excellent addition to this line of games. It plays very similar to Civ V, with major visual upgrades. The tech web is engaging through many playthroughs, and there are constantly ways to slightly adjust the way your Civ upgrades. The game-setup is much improved from prior versions - I really enjoy customizing the strengths of my Civ even before playing the first turn. It's not perfect... the difficulty levels aren't as hard as earlier games, the espionage mechanic needs some tweaking as a few buildings can nerf any effect your agents have... but for all of that, this game is a great exploration of what happens to Civilization after leaving Earth behind.

customer_reviews.title: Buggy and nearly unplayable for the color-blind.  Wait for patches to come out.
customer_reviews.text: Two days of gameplay in, and Civilization Beyond Earth appears to be basically a buggy mod for Civ 5. The color pallete is headache-inducing, and terrain types (grassland vs tundra, for example, since both are light blue - cyan - purplish) are indistinguishable by sight, as are tiles with "miasma" which actually cause unit damage. Some of the new game dynamics look interesting, but the visual design of the game makes it painful to play.

customer_reviews.title: The most improved Civilization game, Ever!
customer_reviews.text: It may not be the absoloute best Civilization game, but it is definitely the most fun to play. This game gives you a fresh take on an old franchise, without compromising what you love about Civ games. The best improvements are the tech tree and the variable game play using certain corporations. You can play a game with one nation, and the next time it will play completely differently. It doesn't force you to choose your strategy based on your civilization, like previous games. It allows you to pick who you would like to play with, then decide how you want to win. Great addition to the civilization series!

product_meta.title: Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth [Online Game Code]
product_meta.description:
Pre-purchase Sid Meier’s Civilization: Beyond Earth and receive the Exoplanets Map Pack for free.

The Exoplanets Map Pack includes six custom maps inspired by real-world exoplanets. Specialized scripts produce randomized geographic layouts each time a new game begins, allowing for even more replayability on new alien worlds. 
 *  Kepler 186f: This lush forest planet is one of the oldest known Earth-like planets. 
 * Rigil Khantoris Bb: Orbiting the closest star to the solar system, the historical records of this arid continental planet’s settlement are well-preserved. 
 * Tau Ceti d: This planet of seas and archipelagos features a booming biodiversity and a wealth of resources. 
 * Mu Arae f: Tidally locked in orbit around a weak star, the southern hemisphere of this planet is a blistering desert where the sun never sets, while the northern hemisphere is perpetually in frozen darkness. 
 * 82 Eridani e: An alien world of scarce water and wracked by tectonic forces. 
 * Eta Vulpeculae b: A mysterious new discovery with unknown terrain. 

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a new science-fiction-themed entry into the award-winning Civilization series. Set in the future, global events have destabilized the world leading to a collapse of modern society, a new world order and an uncertain future for humanity. As the human race struggles to recover, the re-developed nations focus their resources on deep space travel to chart a new beginning for mankind. 

As part of an expedition sent to find a home beyond Earth, you will write the next chapter for humanity as you lead your people into a new frontier and create a new civilization in space. Explore and colonize an alien planet, research new technologies, amass mighty armies, build incredible Wonders and shape the face of your new world. As you embark on your journey you must make critical decisions. From your choice of sponsor and the make-up of your colony, to the ultimate path you choose for your civilization, every decision opens up new possibilities.

Key Features: 

 * Seed the Adventure: Establish your national identity, choosing one of eight different factions, each with its own unique gameplay benefits. Craft your expedition by assembling your spacecraft, cargo & colonists through a series of choices that directly seed the starting conditions when arriving at the new planet. A new quest system guides you as you begin your journey.
 * Colonize an Alien World: Explore the dangers and benefits of a new planet filled with alien terrain, resources, and hostile life forms unlike those of Earth. Build outposts, establish trade routes and develop flourishing cities to create prosperity for your people. 
 * Technology Web: To reflect progress forward into an uncertain future, technology advancement occurs through a series of nonlinear choices that affect the development of mankind.
 * Orbital Layer: Build and deploy advanced military, economic and scientific units that provide strategic offensive, defensive and support capabilities from orbit.
 * Unit Customization: Unlock different upgrades through the tech web and customize your units to reflect your play style. 
 * Contend with Rivals: Wage war, form diplomatic alliances, and engage in espionage in your path to victory against other factions, each with its own leader and different gameplay style. 
 * Multiplayer: Up to 8 players can compete for dominance of a new alien world.
 * Mod support: Robust mod support allows you to customize and extend your game experience.
